document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Bobath popular - but may not be best for Stroke: Eyes on Evidence Commentary
document.topics: <![CDATA[ REHABILITATION,STROKE,JAN-MAR 10,FEBRUARY 2010,RECENT ADDITIONS,PHYSIOTHERAPY,CURRENT AWARENESS - HOT OFF THE PRESS]]>
document.body:
111-1Bobath popular - but may not be best for Stroke: Eyes on Evidence Commentary
 
Bobath - popular but may not be best for stroke

Overview:  In the UK every year 150,000 people have a stroke and it is estimated that of these 10,000 occurrences are in people under retirement age.
As a result of stroke many are living with moderate to severe disabilities, including arm/hand/leg weakness, sensory loss and balance problems.
The direct cost of stroke to the NHS is estimated to be £2.8 billion, with informal care costs estimated at an additional £2.4 billion.

Current Treatment: Physiotherapy is the most common treatment for motor weakness due to stroke. Approaches include Bobath Concept (or neuro developmental treatment), Motor Learning (or motor relearning or movement science approach), Brunnstron, Rood, Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation, and Johnstone.
In the UK the Bobath Concept is the most popular treatment approach used in stroke rehabilitation (Tyson et al 2009a, Tyson et al 2009b). The aim of Bobath treatment is to improve or restore function following neurological impairment. Treatment is tailored to clients' individual needs and is based upon an assessment of their abilities and analysis of their movement disorder. This is achieved through the use of specialised handling techniques that help to reduce spasticity and facilitate more normal movement.
However, SIGN recommends that until further evidence is available, any one approach to treatment should not be assumed to be more efficacious than others in promoting effective rehabilitation.
NICE has guidance in development for stroke rehabilitation with a publication date of April 2012.

New Evidence:  Kollen et al's systematic review examined current evidence specifically on the effectiveness of the Bobath Concept in stroke rehabilitation (Stroke, 2009; 40:e89-e97), based on 16 randomised controlled trials of 813 patients with stroke.
The review found no evidence of superiority of Bobath on sensorimotor control of upper and lower limb, dexterity, mobility, activities of daily living, health-related quality of life, and cost-effectiveness. Only limited evidence was found for balance control in favour of Bobath.
This study highlights the need for further high-quality trials in this area and suggests that evidence-based guidelines rather than therapist preference should determine treatment type.

Commentary: "Overall Kollen et al found no evidence that Bobath was superior to other physiotherapy treatments. This could be interpreted as a reason to carry on using the Bobath Concept (as there is no overwhelming evidence that it is worse than anything else). Alternatively it could be interpreted as a lack of evidence to continue to use it, as it isn't better than anything else. The latter view is supported by a previous authoritative review of all stroke physiotherapy interventions which found evidence to support the use of exercise and intensive task-specific practice, but little or no evidence to support traditional treatment approaches such as Bobath (Van Peppen et al 2004).

"Kollen et al's review provides evidence that 'other approaches' may be more effective than Bobath for mobility but the 'other approaches' varied (problem oriented willed movement, rhythmic auditory stimulation and treadmill training) so it was not possible to specify which alternative interventions were superior. All the selected trials assessing dexterity (n=6) found forced use and constraint induced therapy superior to Bobath, while for sensori-motor control of the upper limb they found three interventions which were superior and four trials where there was no difference, none showed that Bobath was the more effective treatment. So, although the evidence is not definitive, it shows that there are alternatives which are superior to Bobath and therefore should be used in preference to it.
However, doing so would require a fundamental paradigm shift whereby physiotherapists would stop basing their treatment on the Bobath Concept and focus on intensive task-specific practice and exercise.
"These changes could possibly be implemented through the re-organisation of existing resources and have the potential for significant improvements in the efficiency and costs of stroke rehabilitation, due to the reduced length of stay, enduring impairments and activity limitations associated with other therapies". - Dr Sarah Tyson, Reader in Rehabilitation at School of Health, Sport and Rehabilitation, University of Salford

]]>

document.title: Coronary risk evaluation in patients with transient ischemic attack and ischemic stroke : a scientific statement for healthcare professionals from The Stroke Council and The Council On Clinical Cardiology of the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CAUSES AND PRIMARY PREVENTION,STROKE,LATER LIFE,CORONARY ARTERY BYPASS GRAFTS,EXERCISE TOLERANCE TESTS,SURGICAL PROCEDURES,NUCLEAR CARDIOLOGY,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DIAGNOSIS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,ANTI-COAGULANTS,ECHOCARDIOGRAM,ELECTROCARDIOGRAM,CORONARY HEART DISEASE,CORONARY ANGIOGRAPHY & CARDIAC CATHETERISATION,CONDITIONS,STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,VASCULAR,CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This statement is aimed at clinicians and discusses the management and coronary risk evaluation of patients with transient ischaemic attack (TIA) and ischaemic stroke.  Sections are included on prevalence of asymptomatic coronary heart disease (CHD) in patients with TIA or stroke, ischaemic stroke subtype and cardiac risk, testing for unrecognized CHD and treatment of asymptomatic CHD. Document contains studies, tabular information, references and a summary of recommendations.  Readers are referred to related ACC/AHA guidelines where appropriate.  Published in Circulation. 2003;108:1278-90.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Desmoteplase for acute ischaemic stroke : horizon scanning review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,THROMBOLYTICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: Desmoteplase is a recombinant fibrin specific plasminogen activator that is in the planning stages of phase III clinical trials for patients with acute ischaemic stroke within 3-9 hours after symptom onset. Patients need a diffusion / perfusion MRI or perfusion CT prior to therapy. Desmoteplase is administered intravenously as a bolus dose of 90mcg / kg or 125mcg / kg. If successful in trials and licensed desmoteplase would extend the time window for thrombolysis in acute stroke from 3 hours to 9 hours. Two small randomised phase II trials suggest an increase in favourable 90-day patient outcomes from 25% with placebo to 60% for desmoteplase 125mcg / kg.

Background:  This study aims to assess the effectiveness of desmoteplase for acute ischaemic stroke

Access: Abstract only. Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Device for treatment of ischemic stroke
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DISEASE MANAGEMENT,EMERGENCY CARE,SURGICAL INTERVENTIONS,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,STROKE,NEUROSURGERY]]>
document.body:
Authors' conclusions: The Merci Retrieval System is another step in the development of new approaches for treating ischemic stroke. It provides an addition option when thrombolysis has failed or is inappropriate. Use of the device requires a high skill level. Data on the effectiveness of the device are limited. It is expected that the results of ongoing trials will provide further information.

Background: The aim of this study was to review the available information on the use of the Merci Retriever / Merci Retrieval System device to remove blood clots from the brain.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Expansion of the time window for treatment of acute ischemic stroke with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,APR-JUN 09,GENERAL / OTHER,PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
This document from The American Heart Association examines the time window for the treatment of acute ischemic stroke with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator. Each year around 795,000 strokes occur in the United States of America, and of these approximately 600,000 are ischemic.  Current guidelines recommend administration of tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) for acute ischemic stroke within three hours of stroke symptom onset.  Recent results of the European Cooperative Acute Stroke Study (ECASS-3) show evidence of an expanded time window between 3.0 and 4.5 hours for persons experiencing acute ischemic stroke symptoms.

Includes sections on:

  • Top things to know
  • Slide set
  • Guidelines for the Early Management of Adults with Ischemic Stroke
  • Other AHA/ASA statements and guidelines for stroke
  • Get with the guidelines 

Publication history information: Published May 2009.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

 

 

]]>

document.title: Guidelines and recommendations for perfusion imaging in cerebral ischemia : a scientific statement for healthcare professionals by the writing group on perfusion imaging, from the Council on Cardiovascular Radiology of the American Heart Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ GENERAL,MRI SCAN,DIAGNOSIS,DIAGNOSIS,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DIAGNOSIS,STROKE,STROKE,CAUSES AND PRIMARY PREVENTION,LATER LIFE]]>
document.body:
These guidelines summarise current knowledge of the use of perfusion technologies in their role of evaluating acute and chronic cerebral ischaemic conditions. Specific perfusion technologies are discussed including xenon-enhanced computed tomography (XeCT), computed tomography perfusion imaging (CTP), single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) and perfusion-weighted and diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (PWI and DWI). The strengths and weaknesses of each technique are highlighted and recommendations are made for their use and the need for future research. Includes diagrams, summary statement and references. Published in Stroke 2003;34:1084.

Access: Available to the general public.

document.body:
Aims: Carotid endarterectomy is a procedure to remove plaque from the carotid artery to restore blood flow, it may also reduce the risk of stroke. document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Guidelines for the early management of adults with ischemic stroke : a guideline from the American Heart Association / American Stroke Association Stroke Council, Clinical Cardiology Council, Cardiovascular Radiology and Intervention Council and the Atherosclerotic Peripheral Vascular Disease and Quality of Care Outcomes in Research Interdisciplinary Working Groups
document.publisher: American Heart Association, American Stroke Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DIAGNOSIS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,THROMBOLYTICS,SURGICAL INTERVENTIONS]]>
document.body:
Aims: To provide recommendations for the management of ischaemic stroke from the first contact by emergency medical services personnel through to initial admission to the hospital.

The conclusion is reached that intravenous administration of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator remains the most beneficial proven intervention for emergency treatment of stroke. Several interventions, including intra-arterial administration of thrombolytic agents and mechanical interventions show promise. Many of the recommendations are based on limited data, therefore additional research on treatment of acute ischaemic stroke is needed.

Intended audience: Physicians and other emergency healthcare providers who treat patients within the first 48 hours after stroke. In addition, information for healthcare policy makers is included.

Publication history information: Published in May 2007. Supercedes the 1999 and 2003 guidelines.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Guidelines for the early management of patients with ischemic stroke : a scientific statement from The Stroke Council of the American Stroke Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NEUROLOGICAL CONDITIONS,RECENT ADDITIONS,STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,LATER LIFE,STROKE,ACUTE MANAGEMENT,STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DIAGNOSIS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DIAGNOSIS,GENERAL,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,ANTI-PLATELET DRUGS,THROMBOLYTICS,SURGICAL INTERVENTIONS,CONDITIONS,OCTOBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This document is a revision of the 1994 guidelines and provides updated recommendations for the early management of patients with ischaemic stroke. Diagnosis and evaluation is examined and information is included on history and physical examination, brain imaging, cardiac tests and vascular imaging. General supportive care and treatment of acute complications is also considered. Sections are included on intravenous thrombolysis, intra-arterial thrombolysis, anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents. Endovascular treatment and surgical interventions are also discussed.  Includes conclusions and recommendations, tabular information, references and a summary statement. Published in Stroke 2003;34:1056.

Access: Available to the general public.

 

]]>

document.title: Guidelines for the management of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage : a statement for healthcare professionals from a special writing group of the Stroke Council, American Heart Association
document.publisher: American Heart Association, American Stroke Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,INTRACEREBRAL HAEMORRHAGE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,DIAGNOSIS,PREVENTION,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,ALCOHOL DRINKING,DIET,HYPERTENSION,SMOKING,DIAGNOSIS,GENERAL,PREVENTION,DIET,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,SMOKING CESSATION]]>
document.body:
Aims: The aim of this document is to provide guidelines for the management of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and to suggest areas for future research. Strong positive recommendations are limited because there have been only four small randomised controlled trials (RCT) and four small medical trials. Further trials are urgently needed. The following information is provided:

  • emergent diagnosis of ICH and its causes
  • diagnosis of ICH: summary and recommendations
  • treatment of acute ICH
  • surgical treatment of ICH
  • prevention of ICH

Intended audience: Healthcare professionals

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Guidelines for the management of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage in adults : 2007 update : a guideline from the American Heart Association / American Stroke Association Council, High Blood Pressure Research Council and the Quality of Care & Outcomes in Research Interdisciplinary Working Group
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,INTRACEREBRAL HAEMORRHAGE,DIAGNOSIS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,DIAGNOSIS,GENERAL,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,GENERAL / OTHER]]>
document.body:
Aims: To update the 1999 guidelines and present current and comprehensive recommendations for the diagnosis and treatment of acute spontaneous intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH).

In the six years since the 1999 guidelines were published, 15 pilot and larger randomised medical and surgical trials for ICH / intraventricular haemorrhage (IVH) have been completed or are ongoing, which provide hope for new and effective treatments of patients with ICH. A formal literature search of Medline was performed to the end date of August 2006, plus additional articles known to the writing committee.The American Academy of Neurology affirms the value of these guidelines as an educational tool for neurologists. The guidelines cover the following topics:

  • recent trials of recombinant factor VII to slow initial bleeding
  • recommendations for various surgical approaches for treatment of spontaneous ICH
  • withdrawal of care and end of life issues in patients with ICH

Publication history information: Published 1st June 2007

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Guidelines for the prevention of stroke in patients with ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack : a statement for healthcare professionals from the American Heart Association / American Stroke Association Council on Stroke : co-sponsored by the Council on Cardiovascular Radiology and Intervention
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,PREVENTION,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,PREVENTION,PREVENTION,LIPIDS MANAGEMENT,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,SMOKING CESSATION,OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY,HYPERTENSION MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Aim: To provide comprehensive evidence-based recommendations on the prevention of ischemic stroke among survivors of ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack. Evidence-based recommendations are included for:

  • the control of risk factors
  • interventional approaches to atherosclerotic disease
  • antithrombotic treatments for cardioembolism
  • the use of antiplatelet agents for non cardioembolic stroke

In addition, recommendations are given for the prevention of recurrent stroke in:

  • arterial dissections
  • patent foramen ovale
  • hyperhomocysteinaemia
  • hypercoagulable states
  • sickle cell disease
  • cerebral venous sinus thrombosis
  • stroke in women, particularly with regard to pregnancy and the use of postmenopausal hormones
  • the use of anticoagulation after cerebral haemorrhage
  • the use of guidelines in high risk populations

The American Academy of Neurology affirms the value of this guideline.

Intended audience: Healthcare professionals

Publication history information: Published 1st February 2006

Access: Avaiable to the gerneral public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

document.title: Hypertension
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,PREVENTION,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,PREVENTION,COMMON SEQUELAE OF STROKE,APHASIA,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,HYPERTENSION,PREVENTION,HYPERTENSION MANAGEMENT,JAN-MAR 09]]>
document.body:
This is one topic (question 3) from a series of frequently asked questions about stroke prevention by the practitioner, produced by the European Stroke Organization (ESO).  The cases covered for this topic are:

  • Aphasia, left hemiparesis and high blood pressure
  • High blood pressure, otherwise symptomless

document.title: Implementation strategies for emergency medical services within stroke systems of care. A policy statement from the American Heart Association / American Stroke Association Expert Panel on Emergency Medical Services Systems and the Stroke Council
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,DIAGNOSIS,GENERAL,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,EMERGENCY CARE,PRE-HOSPITAL,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,SPECIALIST STROKE UNITS]]>
document.body:
This policy statement from the American Heart Association / American Stroke Association aims to assist in the development and improvement of stroke systems of care in the emergency setting. Emergency medical services and the organisation of resources for the delivery of these services play a critical role in optimising stroke care. Recomendations fall within four catergories:

  • processes need to be in place to ensure rapid access to emergency medical services for acute stroke patients
  • protocols, tools and training should be in place that meet ASA / AHA guidelines for stroke care 
  • training, assessment, treatment and transportation protocols for stroke patients should be developed 
  • patients should be transported to the nearest stroke centre for evaluation and care, wherever there is one close enough for acute therapeutic interventions

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: IS109 : The influence of developmental indices and blood pressure in young adults on risk of stroke and coronary heart disease in later life
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CAUSES AND RISK FACTORS,CONDITIONS,HYPERTENSION,HYPERTENSION,LATER LIFE,STROKE,BACKGROUND,CAUSES AND PRIMARY PREVENTION,STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,HYPERTENSION]]>
document.body:
Authors' conclusion: The marked secular decline in BP in both males and females over 20 years from 1948-68 provides empirical evidence that current declines in CVD mortality (and incidence) may be due in part to declines in the prevalence of important risk factors - in this case BP level - in the past. Since BP was measured in early adults, factors driving the downward trend must be operating in childhood. Furthermore the positive association between BP measured in early adulthood and later CVD mortality also points to the importance of such early life factors in future disease and shows that CVD risk originates at least as far back as young adulthood. Efforts to understand the mechanism of BP determination in this age group and to explain how BP at this early age increases CVD risk in later life are required. Work currently in progress (on regression dilution bias and height and subsequent CVD mortality) will add to the value of these findings.

Methods: 15,332 students (approximately 50% of the student population) who attended the University of Glasgow from 1948-68 participated in a survey of student health. Almost a quarter of the students were female. Data collected from a detailed questionnaire and medical examination include: socio-demographic, behavioural, developmental, anthropometric, and clinical details, as well as details of medical history and family health and structure. Data are over 95% complete for most variables. Over 40% of students were examined on two or more occasions. Over 90% of students were from social classes I-III. Eighty-two per cent (12,553/15,322) of the students have been traced and flagged through the National Health Service Central Register. To date 1111 (7.2%) of those traced have died.

Results: Blood pressure trends, determinants and relation to cardiovascular mortality are provided.

Access to abstract: Available to the general public.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Lowering blood pressure to prevent myocardial infarction and stroke : a new preventive strategy
document.publisher: National Co-ordinating Centre for Health Technology Assessment, Wessex Institute for Health Research and Development
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,CONDITIONS,ANTI-HYPERTENSIVE DRUGS,BETA BLOCKERS,CALCIUM CHANNEL BLOCKERS,DIURETICS,HYPERTENSION,ACE INHIBITORS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,ACUTE CORONARY SYNDROMES,MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION,PREVENTION,STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,PREVENTION,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,PREVENTION,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SECONDARY PREVENTION,ANTI-HYPERTENSIVE DRUGS,ACE INHIBITORS,BETA-BLOCKERS,CALCIUM CHANNEL BLOCKERS,PREVENTION,HYPERTENSION MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Bottom-line conclusion: Three blood pressure lowering drugs in combination may reduce stroke by about two-thirds and ischaemic heart disease by half. The review recommends that this type of preventative therapy be considered for wider user in people who are at risk of a heart attack or stroke regardless of their initial blood pressure.

Methods: Relevant cohort studies and randomised trails were identified and analysed. Statistical analysis was used to determine drug efficacy and adverse effects.

Results:Lowering blood pressure by 5 mmHG diastolic reducing the risk of stroke by an estimated 34% and ischaemic heart disease by 21% from any pre-treatment level; there is no threshold.

Blood pressure is a poor predictor of cardiovascular events (despite its importance in causing cardiovascular disease) e.g. persons in the top 10% of the distribution of systolic blood pressue experienced only 21% of all ischaemic heart disease events and 28% of all strokes at a given age.

The main method of screening should be to identify all persons with a history of cardiovascular disease events and to use a person's age. Identifying everyone with a history of myocardial infarction or stroke in a population and everyone aged 55 or more would include 98% of all deaths from ischeamic heart disease and stroke.

The five main categories of blood pressue lowering drugs; thiazides, beta-blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin-II receptor antagonists and calcium channel blockers; significantly reduce blood pressure from all pre-treatment levels.

The reductions were similiar at standard doses for all drugs. The effect of combinations of two drugs on blood pressure was additive.  No effect of age was apparent, given blood pressure. There were no serious metabolic consequences of using these drugs in standard dose.

Citation: Law M, Wald N, Morris J. Lowering blood pressure to prevent myocardial infarction and stroke: a new preventive strategy. Health Technology Assessment. Vol 7 No.31, 2003

Publication history information: Published in November 2003

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: National Sentinel Stroke Audit Organisational Audit 2010
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,KEY POLICIES AND RELATED PUBLICATIONS,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,CLINICAL AUDIT AND GOVERNANCE,PERFORMANCE INDICATORS,SERVICE MODELS,RECENT ADDITIONS,NOVEMBER 2010,OCT-DEC 10]]>
document.body:
This report presents the results from the National Sentinel Stroke Audit of the Organisation of Stroke Care 2010 in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and thebIslands Round 7. Since Round 1 in 1998 the Sentinel audit has been measuring the organisation of stroke services and the care provided for stroke patients in acute NHS trusts. The main recommendations include:

  • Patients with acute stroke should be admitted directly to specialist stroke beds and have access to continuous physiological monitoring. General assessment units are not an adequate substitute.
  • Standards of care offered in all specialist stroke beds should meet those defined in the National Clinical Guideline for Stroke 2008.
  • Stroke services should be organised to deliver thrombolysis to all appropriate patients regardless of where they live or the time of day or week they present.
  • Patients requiring end of life care should be able to receive such care to a high standard on a stroke unit.
  • High quality longer term rehabilitation should be provided to all patients who require on-going treatment without undue delay.
  • Facilities to investigate high risk patients after TIA should be available at all times including weekends.
  • Information provision should be improved to provide universal access to all inpatients and out-patients.

 

Publication history information: Published in August 2010.

Access: Available to the general public.  Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: National sentinel stroke audit: phase I organisational audit 2008
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,STROKE,CLINICAL AUDIT AND GOVERNANCE,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,SERVICE MODELS,PERFORMANCE INDICATORS,KEY POLICIES AND RELATED PUBLICATIONS,JAN-MAR 09]]>
document.body:
The audit looked at all aspects of stroke care and has made a series of recommendations covering everything from acute care to community stroke care. The main recommendations include:

  • All patients with acute stroke should be admitted directly to an acute stroke unit equipped and staffed to be able to deliver high quality care.
  • Thrombolysis should only be provided when all the other components of acute stroke care are of high quality.
  • All hospitals managing stroke and transient ischaemic attack (TIA) patients need to ensure they comply with the recommendations in the NICE guidelines for acute stroke and TIA for imaging, and the Department of Health's document on imaging after stroke and TIA.
  • Hospitals should make sure they do not have patients without stroke occupying beds in the stroke unit while stroke patients are managed off the unit.
  • Stroke services should urgently review policies that exclude certain groups from admission to the stroke unit - for example where there is judged to be ‘no rehabilitation potential' - as there is no evidence to support such a policy.
  • Levels of nurse staffing on acute stroke units need to be increased in many units.

Publication history information: Published in August 2008.

Access: Available to the general public.  Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.title: National Stroke Strategy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ LATER LIFE,STROKE,SERVICE ORGANISATION,ACUTE MANAGEMENT,REHABILITATION,SECONDARY PREVENTION,PUBLIC HEALTH,STROKE,OUTCOMES,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,CIRCULATORY DISEASES,STROKE & TIA,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,STRATEGY,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,KEY POLICIES AND RELATED PUBLICATIONS,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,PERFORMANCE INDICATORS,SERVICE MODELS,VASCULAR,CONDITIONS,NATIONAL STROKE STRATEGY]]>
document.body:
Aims: This national strategy is intended to provide a quality framework to secure improvements to stroke services, to provide guidance and support to commissioners and strategic health authorities and social care, and inform the expectations of patients and their families by providing a guide  to high quality health/social care services.

document.title: National target indicators for ambulance trusts 2007/2008.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,EMERGENCY CARE,PREVENTION,OVERWEIGHT AND OBESITY,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,PERFORMANCE INDICATORS,JAN-MAR 10,RECENT ADDITIONS,FEBRUARY 2010]]>
document.body:
The Care Quality Commission (formerly The Healthcare Commission) will be using five indicators to assess the performance of ambulance trusts against the new as described in National Standards, Local Action: Health and Social Care Standards and Planning Framework 2005/2006 – 2007/2008, published by the Department of Health in July 2004). This document includes details of the rationale, the data source, the data period and the constructions for each indicator. These indicators include:

  • emergency response to stroke and transient ischaemic attack 
  • infection control 
  • obesity: compliance with NICE guidance 43 
  • participation in audits 
  • self harm: compliance with NICE and JRCALC guidelines 

Publication history information: Published March 2007 and up-dated November 2007.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

The Neurological Conditions Specialist Library (NCSL) aims to provide access to the best available evidence within neurological conditions to NHS healthcare professionals. document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: NHS Stroke Improvement Website
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,NATIONAL STROKE STRATEGY,JAN-MAR 10,NETWORKS,NHS HEALTH IMPROVEMENT PROGRAMMES,MANAGEMENT ISSUES]]>
document.body:
The Stroke Improvement Programme (SIP) was set up to provide national support for local improvement of stroke and TIA services. It is an NHS initiative to support the development of Stroke Care Networks and the implementation of the National Stroke Strategy.

In addition to the programme of support and development for Stroke Care Networks, SIP provides regular educational events and conferences, and undertakes national improvement projects. SIP provides a wide range of expertise on how to begin, manage and sustain service improvements that benefit patients and staff. SIP works closely with the Department of Health, the Stroke Association, and other organisations working in the stroke field.

 

Access: Available to the general public.

document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,REHABILITATION,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,REHABILITATION,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,EMERGENCY CARE,ACUTE STROKE CARE,THROMBOLYTICS,SECONDARY PREVENTION,ANTI-PLATELET DRUGS,ASPIRIN,DIPYRIDAMOLE,ANTI-HYPERTENSIVE DRUGS,ACE INHIBITORS,ANTICOAGULANTS,WARFARIN,REHABILITATION,GENERAL/OTHER,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,PERFORMANCE INDICATORS]]>
document.body:
The aim of the Stroke Task Force is to raise the profile of quality stroke care through:

  • Increasing the profile of stroke prevention and management within Primary Care Groups and Acute Trusts.
  • Dissemination of evidence based standards for stroke management to Health Authorities, Primary Care Groups and Acute Trusts.
  • Working in areas of high mortality to try to improve prevention and management of stroke, particularly in those areas where stroke mortality rates are rising.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Occupational therapy audit package for stroke : second edition
document.topics: <![CDATA[ REHABILITATION,REHABILITATION,REHABILITATION,STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,SERVICE MODELS,PERFORMANCE INDICATORS,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY,OCT-DEC 09]]>
document.body:
The occupational therapy audit package for stroke : second edition, is a profession specific audit.  The package provides basic standards, based on the 'National clinical guidelines for stroke: second edition'.  The audit is divided into two sections - organisational and clinical and covers the following standards:

  • Service structure
  • Process of care
  • Goal setting and intervention
  • Discharge from hospital
  • Discharge from occupational therapy

 

Each standard is followed by criteria taking the form of key clinical activities which should be performed in order for each standard to be achieved. A range of outcome measures are included at the end of the document.


 

Publication history information: Published in May 2007.

 

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Occupational therapy standards for stroke : February 2008
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,REHABILITATION,REHABILITATION,REHABILITATION,OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,CLINICAL AUDIT AND GOVERNANCE,OCT-DEC 08]]>
document.body:
One of a series of profession-specific standards produced by the Royal College of Physicians in association with the college of each profession.  The standards are to be used in conjunction with the Sentinel Audit and are designed for use in a hospital setting following acute stroke.

 

The audit proforma state the minimum standards which should be met by any occupational therapy stroke service.  Each standard is followed by criteria which take the form of key clinical activities which should be performed in order for the standard to be achieved.  The following areas are covered:

  • service structure
  • process of care
  • goal setting and intervention
  • transfer / discharge from OT
  • aspects of outcome which occupational therapists may wish to evaluate

Publication history information:  Published in February 2008

Access: Available to the general public.  Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Other risk factors for stroke
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,JAN-MAR 09]]>
document.body:
This is one topic (question 6) from a series of frequently asked questions about stroke prevention by the practitioner, produced by the European Stroke Organization (ESO).  The questions answered for this topic are:

  • Cigarette smoking is a definite risk factor for myocardial infarction and lower limb arteriopath: what about cigarettes and risk of stroke?
  • Which of cigarette smoking and arterial hypertension is the most important risk factor for stroke?
  • Increased fibrinogen plasma concentration is an established risk marker for myocardial infarction: does it also identify a population at risk of stroke?
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia emerged recently as a vascular risk marker, both in arterial and venous systems: why is this marker so important?
  • Resistance to activated protein C is associated with a point mutation in the gene of coagulation factor V (factor V leiden)... is this mutation associated with an increased risk of cerebrovascular events?
  • In the presence of ulcerated plaques in the aortic arch, what is the risk of stroke?
  • In a patient with stroke, do ulcerations in the aortic arch increase the risk of recurrent stroke?
  • What is the relationship between stroke and alchol consumption?
  • What is the relationship between oral contraception and stroke?

Access: Available to the general public.

Information last checked by information specialist in September 2010.

]]>

document.title: Physical activity and public health : updated recommendation for adults from the American College of Sports Medicine and American Heart Association
document.publisher: American Heart Association, American College of Sports Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,PREVENTION,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,PUBLIC HEALTH,STROKE,DETERMINANTS,BIOLOGICAL COMPOSITION,OBESITY,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,LIFESTYLE,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,ADULTS,SERVICES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,PREVENTION,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,PREVENTION,PREVENTION,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY]]>
document.body:
Aims: To update and clarify the 1995 recommendations on the types and amounts of physical activity needed by healthy adults to improve and maintain health. The primary recommendations include:

  • all healthy adults aged 18-65 need moderate intensity aerobic physical activity (for example a brisk walk) for a minimum of 30 minutes five days a week, or
  • vigorous intensity aerobic activity (for example jogging) for a minimum of 20 minutes three days a week

Publication history information: Published 28th August 2007


Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Physical activity and public health in older adults : recommendation from the American College of Sports Medicine and the American Heart Association
document.publisher: American Heart Association, American College of Sports Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,PREVENTION,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,PUBLIC HEALTH,STROKE,DETERMINANTS,BIOLOGICAL COMPOSITION,OBESITY,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,SOCIAL DETERMINANTS,LIFESTYLE,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS,ADULTS,SERVICES,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,PREVENTION,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,PREVENTION,PREVENTION,PHYSICAL ACTIVITY,OLDER PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
Aims: The aim of this document is to provide recommendations on the types and amounts of physical activity needed to improve and maintain health in older adults. The recommendation for older adults is similar to the updated ACSM / AHA recommendation for adults, but has several important differences including:

  • the recommended intensity of aerobic activity  needs to account for the older adult’s aerobic fitness
  • activities that maintain or increase flexibility are recommended and balance exercises for those at risk of falls
  • older adults should have an activity plan for achieving recommended physical activity that integrates preventive and therapeutic recommendations
  • the promotion of physical activity in older adults should emphasize moderate intensity aerobic activity, muscle-strengthening activity, reducing sedentary behavior, and risk management 

Publication history information: Published 28th August 2007


Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Prevention in atrial fibrillation and other cardiac sources of embolism
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,CONDITIONS,ANTI-COAGULANTS,ANTI-PLATELET DRUGS,ARRHYTHMIA,ASPIRIN,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,WARFARIN,STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,CARDIAC CAUSES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SECONDARY PREVENTION,ANTI-PLATELET DRUGS,ANTICOAGULANTS,PREVENTION,GENERAL / OTHER,JAN-MAR 09,JAN-MAR 09]]>
document.body:
This is one topic (question 10) from a series of frequently asked questions about stroke prevention by the practitioner, produced by the European Stroke Organization (ESO).  The questions answered for this topic are:

  • What is the percentage of ischemic stroke of cardioembolic origin?
  • Is it possible to identify cardioembolic origins from clinical presentation in patients suffering stroke?
  • What are the risk factors for stroke among people with nonrheumatic atrial fibrillation?
  • Except for atrial fibrillation, what are the cardiac sources of stroke?
  • What is the annual risk of stroke in people with chronic atrial fibrillation as compared with people with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation?
  • What are the rationales for oral anticoagulants in patients with atrial fibrillation?
  • What are the main results of randomized trials comparing anticoagulants and aspirin for primary prevention in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation?
  • What is the usual target range of the international normalized ratio of the prothrombin time in patients with atrial fibrillation?
  • What are the major recommendations for primary prevention with oral anticoagulants in atrial fibrillation?
  • What are the main results of large trials of secondary prevention with oral anticoagulants in atrial fibrillation?
  • Is there any clinical situation where antithrombotic prophylaxis with warfarin seems not to be warranted?
  • What are the main results of large trials of secondary prevention comparing oral anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation and aspirin?
  • What is the role of echocardiography in the management of patients with atrial fibrillation?

Access: Available to the general public.

Information last checked by information specialist in September 2010.

]]>

document.publisher: American Heart Association, American Stroke Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,PREVENTION,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,PREVENTION,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,ALCOHOL DRINKING,DIABETES MELLITUS,GENETICS,HYPERTENSION,SMOKING,PREVENTION,PRIMARY PREVENTION]]>
document.body:
Aims: This guideline concludes that there is extensive evidence available identifying a variety of specific factors that increase the risk of a first stroke and providing strategies for reducing that risk. This guideline updates the 2001 review, using systematic literature reviews published between 2001 and January 2005. The document:

  • evaluates schemes for assessing a person’s risk of a first stroke
  • classifies risk factors or risk markers for a first stroke according to their potential for modification
  • reviews data on the use of aspirin for primary stroke prevention

document.title: Profession specific audit of stroke 2006: a multidisciplinary pilot study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,REHABILITATION,REHABILITATION,REHABILITATION,OCT-DEC 08,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,CLINICAL AUDIT AND GOVERNANCE,PERFORMANCE INDICATORS,GENERAL/OTHER]]>
document.body:
This report was produced by the Intercollegiate Working Party for Stroke (IWPS) and details the results of the pilot of a national, multi-disciplinary audit of stroke services undertaken in 2006.  The profession-specific audit standards produced by the Royal College of Physicians in association with profession-specific colleges were used for the purpose of this audit. 

The report includes sections on:

  • Background and information
  • Profession specific sections:
    • Nursing services
    • Nutrition and dietetic services
    • Occupational therapy services
    • Physiotherapy services
    • Speech and language therapy services
  • Multiprofessional performance across domains

A total of 30 Trusts took part in the pilot and as a result, recommendations are made for each of the professional groups and also for how the audit could be used in the future.

Publication history information:  Published in May 2007.

Access:  Available to the general public.  Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Progress in improving stroke care : a good practice guide
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,STROKE,SERVICE DELIVERY,NHS ACTIVITIES,QUALITY AND MONITORING,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,JAN-MAR 10,NATIONAL STROKE STRATEGY,RECENT ADDITIONS,FEBRUARY 2010,QUALITY IMPROVEMENT,NATIONAL AUDIT OFFICE REPORTS,CLINICAL AUDIT AND GOVERNANCE,MANAGEMENT ISSUES]]>
document.body:
The National Audit Office evaluation of how stroke care has changed over the last four years, the extent to which these changes have improved the value for money of stroke care provision nationally, and the risks and issues to be managed to ensure that stroke care services continue to improve in future. [HC 291 Session 2009-2010]

This report formed the basis of a hearing of the Committee of Public Accounts, whose report in June 2006 concluded that the human and economic costs of stroke could be reduced by re-organising services and using existing capacity more wisely. The Committee made a number of recommendations for the Department of Health (the Department) and NHS organisations, and asked the National Audit Office to report back on progress in improving stroke care.

]]>

document.body:
Recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) was approved a decade ago for the treatment of acute ischemic stroke. The guidelines for its use include stroke onset within 3 hours of intravenous drug administration, preceded by a computed tomographic (CT) scan to exclude the presence of hemorrhage, which is a contraindication to the use of the drug.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Recommendations for the endovascular treatment of intracranial aneurysms : a statement for healthcare professionals from the Committee on Cerebrovascular Imaging of the American Heart Association Council on Cardiovascular Radiology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGICAL INTERVENTIONS,VASCULAR SURGERY]]>
document.body:
Aims: These guidelines provide recommendations on endovascular therapy of ruptured and unruptured intracranial aneurysms. Recommendations are based on expert opinion with evidence only available from nonrandomised cohort studies and case series. Randomised controlled trials are needed. The guidelines conclude that:

  • evidence about the role of endovascular therapy is limited, although the literature suggests it has an important role when the aneurysm is difficult to treat surgically
  • special consideration should be given to coil embolisation if surgery is difficult or impossible
  • if coil embolisation and surgery are difficult or impossible, endovascular occlusion is a treatment option

Intended audience: Healthcare professionals


Publication history information: Published 1st October 2002


Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.title: Recommendations for the management of intracranial arteriovenous malformations : a statement for healthcare professionals from a special writing group of the Stroke Council, American Stroke Association
document.publisher: American Heart Association, American Stroke Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,CAUSES / RISK FACTORS,VESSEL DISSECTION,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,EMERGENCY CARE,ACUTE STROKE CARE,CEREBRAL MONITORING,SURGICAL INTERVENTIONS,NEUROSURGERY]]>
document.body:
Aims: Patients with intracranial arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are at risk of haemorrhage or other neurological symptoms. More than 50% of intracranial AVMs present with intracranial haemorrhage, although brain imaging techniques have helped to detect an increasing number before rupture. There are currently four major treatment options for AVMs:

  • monitoring
  • intervention, either single or combined therapy of the following:
    • microsurgery
    • endovascular techniques
    • radiosurgery

Intended audience: Healthcare professionals

Publication history information: Published 1st June 2001

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Recommendations for the management of patients with unruptured intracranial aneurysms : a statement for healthcare professionals from the Stroke Council of the American Heart Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGICAL INTERVENTIONS,NEUROSURGERY,VASCULAR SURGERY]]>
document.body:
Aims: These guidelines are intended to serve as a framework for the development of treatments for persons with unruptured intracranial aneurysms (UIA) and as a basis for future research. Further research is needed to confirm or modify the recommendations, which may not apply in all situations.

The document provides information on the factors that favour surgery and those that favour conservative management of UIA:

Factors that favour surgery:

  • young patients
  • previously ruptured aneurysms
  • family history
  • large aneurysms
  • symptomatic aneurysms
  • observed aneurysm growth
  • low treatment risks

Factors that favour conservative management:

  • older patients
  • decreased life expectancy
  • comorbid medical conditions
  • asymptomatic small aneurysms

Intended audience: Healthcare professionals


Publication history information: Published 31st October 2000


Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,PREVENTION,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,EMERGENCY CARE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,REHABILITATION,REHABILITATION,PREVENTION,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,REHABILITATION,SERVICE MODELS,NATIONAL AUDIT OFFICE REPORTS,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,KEY POLICIES AND RELATED PUBLICATIONS,GENERAL / OTHER,PREVENTION,GENERAL/OTHER]]>
document.body:
This report by the National Audit Office is a review of NHS stroke care services in England, in terms of acute response, rehabilitation and prevention and whether the Department of Health is managing and supporting the programme of stroke care well.

The report outlines current stroke care provision and identifies areas where further improvements could be made.

Access: Available to the general public.  Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Reducing delay in seeking treatment of patients with acute coronary syndrome and stroke: a scientific statement from the American Heart Association Council on Cardiovascular Nursing and Stroke Council
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,CONDITIONS,ACUTE CORONARY SYNDROMES,STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Aims: Patient delay in seeking treatment for acute coronary syndrome and stroke symptoms is the major factor limiting delivery of definitive treatment in these conditions. This statement offers suggestions for clinical practice and future research and summarises the evidence that:

  • demonstrates the benefits of early treatment
  • describes the extent of the problem of patient delay
  • identifies the factors related to patient delay in seeking timely treatment
  • reveals the inadequcies of current approaches to decreasing patient delay

Publication history information: Published 11th July 2006


Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Stroke rehabilitation guide: supporting London commissioners to commission quality services 2010/11
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,REHABILITATION,NATIONAL STROKE STRATEGY,APRIL 2010,APR-JUN 10,RECENT ADDITIONS,MANAGEMENT ISSUES]]>
document.body:
The centralisation of acute stroke services was a key proposal of Lord Darzi's 2007 report Healthcare for London: A Framework for Action. Following two public consultations, Consulting the Capital and The Shape of Things to Come, a joint committee of London’s PCTs decided upon the future model of London’s acute stroke care in July 2009. Although the acute pathway was the emphasis of these consultations, Healthcare for London remained aware of the importance of the non-acute parts of the stroke pathway.

This guidance should inform PCTs' commissioning intentions for 2010/11. Improved rehabilitation services and reduced inqualities of access across London will help drive the acute stroke system and provide better outcomes for patients.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Stroke Research Network
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,STROKE,NETWORKS,MANAGEMENT ISSUES]]>
document.body:
"The Stroke Research Network consists of a managed set of research networks and a co-ordinating centre. Research networks are regionally based, collaborative groups of clinical and professional staff working in stroke services, researchers in stroke, and people who have had a stroke and their carers. The networks are virtual organisations, funded by the health departments in the UK countries and supported by a host organisation, usually a NHS Trust. The role of networks is to increase participation in research studies of people who have had a stroke or are at risk of a stroke, as well as involving them and their carers in network activities." This website provides information on the individual stroke networks in the UK.

 

Access: Available to the general public.  Registration is required to access some parts of the website. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Stroke services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,DIAGNOSIS,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,GENERAL / OVERVIEWS,DIAGNOSIS,DIAGNOSIS,GENERAL,MANAGEMENT ISSUES,SERVICE MODELS,SPECIALIST STROKE UNITS,JAN-MAR 09]]>
document.body:
This is one topic (question 11) from a series of frequently asked questions about stroke prevention by the practitioner, produced by the European Stroke Organization (ESO).  The questions answered for this topic are:

  • What organization type should a stroke service unit have?
  • What is the minimal infrastructure that is needed to run a stroke unit?
  • What is the importance to have a neurologist performing diagnosis of stroke syndromes in the early stage of stroke?
  • Which type of hospital should run a stroke service or unit?
  • Should access to stroke services be limited by age, clinical syndromes, or etiological factors?
  • How many diagnosis tests (excluding standard laboratory tests) should the 'average' stroke patient get until final diagnosis?
  • What are the costs of diagnostic work-up to perform etiopathogenic diagnosis in stroke patients?
  • Are savings from secondary prevention (such as antihypertensive therapy after stroke or after carotid endarterectomy) quantifiable?

Access: Available to the general public.

Information last checked by information specialist in September 2010.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: The recognition and emergency management of suspected stroke and TIA guidelines supplement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DIAGNOSIS,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,DIAGNOSIS,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,DIAGNOSIS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,EMERGENCY CARE,TOOLS TO IDENTIFY STROKE,VASCULAR,CONDITIONS,UNSURE,OCT-DEC 09]]>
document.body:
Aims: The aims of the guidelines are:

  • To provide explicit recommendations for practising clinicians, managers, patients and carers about the recognition and emergency management of suspected stroke and transient ischemic attack (TIA), from the onset of symptoms to acute intervention in Accident and Emergency Departments.
  • To provide recommendations based on best available evidence.
  • To give consensus statements from the working party where evidence is lacking.

Intended audience:  This document is intended to be relevant to practising clinicians, managers, patients and carers dealing with the recognition and early management of suspected stroke and TIA.

Methodology and development: The Guidelines were developed by the National Pre-hospital Guidelines Group following the protocol used in the National Clinical Guidelines for Stroke. Members of the working party, listed in the front of this supplement, were nominated by professional organisations and societies to give wide representation from all disciplines, including the views of patients and their families. The guidelines were developed through consensus meetings of the National Pre-hospital Guidelines Group and feedback from the Intercollegiate Working Party for Stroke.

Publication history: Published in June 2006.

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: Update to the AHA / ASA recommendations for the prevention of stroke in patients with stroke and transient ischemic attack
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,PREVENTION,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SECONDARY PREVENTION,ANTI-PLATELET DRUGS,LIPID REGULATING DRUGS,STATINS,PREVENTION,LIPIDS MANAGEMENT,GENERAL / OTHER,VASCULAR,CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
Aims:  This statement is an update of the 2006 guidelines. It provides a brief overview of new data, updates specific recommendations and provides the reasons for modification. In particular, information is provided for the following two areas in which major new clinical trials have been published:

  • the use of specific antiplatelet agents for stroke prevention in patients with a history of noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)
  • the use of statins in the prevention of recurrent stroke.

Publication history information: Published 1st May 2008

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>

document.body:
This revised vascular programme briefing pack was prepared in 2009 to provide the ten strategic health authorities with an assessment of progress, opportunities and future challenges in key areas of vascular disease.

The pack covers coronary heart disease, stroke, diabetes and renal disease. It provides data about these four conditions from the various sources available (QOF and HES, for example).

 

Access: Available to the general public. 

 

Published: Revised 29th April 2009

document.name: <![CDATA[ Stroke]]>
document.title: What's the emergency : a report on the emergency response to stroke
document.topics: <![CDATA[ STROKE,ISCHAEMIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,HAEMORRHAGIC STROKE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRANSIENT ISCHAEMIC ATTACK,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,EMERGENCY CARE,PRE-HOSPITAL,EMERGENCY BRAIN IMAGING]]>
document.body:
"People who have had a stroke have better outcomes if their stroke is treated as an emergency.  Yet stroke is not consistently being identified as a medical emergency by the general public, GPs and Accident and Emergency staff".

The Stroke Association launched its Stroke is a Medical Emergency campaign in October 2005.  The purpose of this report is to outline the "gold standard" of emergency stroke care.

The report covers:

  • the impact of stroke
  • why stroke consistently needs to be treated as a medical emergency
  • the current provision of emergency response to stroke
  • what is needed to ensure the outcomes of stroke improve

Access: Available to the general public.  Portable Document File requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

]]>
